container-title: followed in August 1973 [6]. The SIM-4 was not a computer, but a design aid to facilitate the development of microprocessor applications. Implementation of the microprocessor in commercial computing really started with the European Micral
title: Intel Intel introduced large-scale integrated memory chips and microprocessors in the early 1970’s, providing the basis for low-cost personal microcomputers. The company released the 4-bit, 4004-based SIM-4 simulator board – the first commercial product incorporating a microprocessor – in May 1972, followed by the 8008-based SIM-8.
